advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> ...You will get more performances than with the IBM PC, the Apple II, TRS80 Model II or TRS80 Model III along with software support of TRSDOS or CP/M, the two most widely used operating systems. This means you, the user, can select from the largest base of business or personal software... <font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #1 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, the personal micro which has talents of a pro"...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT JULY 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert introduced three new Digital professional computers: the <b>Professional 300 Series</b>, the <b>DECmate II</b>, and the <b>Rainbow 100</b> <br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">All that personal computers needed were a few professional standards. <br><br> Until now, manufacturer have made personal computers that were a hopeful compromise between home and use business. But now, Digital Equipment Corporation offers the first personal computers designed and built strictly for professional use. And since different professionals have different needs, Digital is introducing not one, but three personal computers made to professional standards.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>School teaching with a Goupil 2</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 36 MHZ. IN 1982?</strong></font><br><blockquote>The title of this advert was very optimistic. In fact, the 36 Mhz speed is obtained by adding the speed of the 9 x Z80 cards installed into the system. The maximum system speed was in fact 4 Mhz.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DAK ADVERT (US, 1986) - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dak.com" target="_blank">DAK</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> HEATH 19 TERMINAL (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>$595 was the price in kit form, F.O.B. Benton Harbor...<br> The assembled version, called Zenith Z-19, costed $895. An expensive price, not compatible with a home computer budget. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Kaypro, it runs" ! <br><br> "Kaypro, the computer which can be carried away" <br><br> "Elected Transportable Computer of the year"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french brochure presented games from #1 to #43</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>More power for less money</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Basis 108. Microcomputin'g "Best Of Both Worlds"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #2 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The columbia MPC is shipped with fully suported software that will save you $3,000. Included is the entire self-teaching Perfect Software family: Perfect Writer, a word processor; Perfect Speller, a 50,000 word dictionnary; Perfect Filer, a data base manager; and Perfect Calc, a financial calculation system.<br><br> In addition, you get MS-DOS, CP/M-86, Macro/86 assembler, BASICA, Asynchronous communication support, Diagnostics and the Columbia Tutor program...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #2 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, software in profusion"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.atarihq.com/tsr/">ITSR'S NES ARCHIVE</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to chrism3667 for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT (1989)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This brochure was jointly published by Philips and American Interactive Media (the Philips/PolyGram joint venture that was set up to develop CD-i consumer software prior to the launch of the hardware). It was intented to give a general overview of CD-i's functionality in a consumer area. The brochure was presented to visitors of multimedia fairs and business partners at around 1989. The CD-i unit (including the remote control) that is displayed is an artist's impression of a player, it was never actually produced. The first consumer CD-i player, the CDI 910, appeared on the market in the US in October 1991. <br><br> <font color="#666666">Source = <a href="http://www.icdia.org/" target="_blank">The New International CD-i Association</a></font><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.icdia.org/" target="_blank">The New International CD-i Association</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND REVIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>Review from a New Zealand magazine. Notice the prices in Australian$ at the bottom right of the page.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>

computer.description:
This computer wasn't 100% MS-DOS compatible, but is intended to work under EOS 16. EOS 16 is an operating system, which looks like UNIX and is fully compatible with Concurrent CP/M and CP/M 86 and can execute programs for MS-DOS 1.4 or MS-DOS 2.0.
Sharp developed a Z80 card for the MZ 5600, with this card, EOS 16 can execute programs written for EOS V3 (EOS for 8 bit systems) or CP/M 80.
The EOS 16 shell is very powerful and uses UNIX features.
The MZ 5600 supports several disk formats: 640 KB (when it is used with MSDOS), 800 KB (to use programs written for the MZ 3541) or 320 KB (old MS-DOS format).

item.description: French FDD unit||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH FDD UNIT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Instead of selling the original Sharp FDD unit, the Sharp French subsidiary (Sharp Burotype Machines) preferred to made their own unit. The case could hold up to 4 drives. The drives were Canon models.</blockquote>
MZ 80P3 - Dot Matrix Printer||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MZ 80P3 - DOT MATRIX PRINTER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.name: MZ 5500 - 5600
computer.ram: 256 KB (up to 512 KB) (Sharp MZ 5521), 128 KB (MZ 5501, MZ 5511)
